example: Le chat est mignon. (The cat is cute.)
Le chien court dans le parc. (The dog runs in the park.)
J'habite dans une maison. (I live in a house.)
Elle a une voiture rouge. (She has a red car.)
Je mange une pomme. (I am eating an apple.)
Il boit de l'eau. (He is drinking water.)
Nous marchons dans la rue. (We walk in the street.)

when_to_say: When talking about liking or loving something.
example: J'aime le chocolat. (I like chocolate.)
Je lis un livre. (I am reading a book.)
L'école est fermée aujourd'hui. (The school is closed today.)
La fleur est belle. (The flower is beautiful.)
L'arbre est grand. (The tree is tall.)
La pomme est rouge. (The apple is red.)
Le ciel est bleu. (The sky is blue.)
Les fleurs sont jaunes. (The flowers are yellow.)
L'herbe est verte. (The grass is green.)

when_to_say: When referring to a female cat.
example: La chatte dort. (The female cat is sleeping.)
L'arbre fruitier porte des pommes. (The fruit tree bears apples.)
Le papillon vole dans le jardin. (The butterfly is flying in the garden.)
La vache mange de l'herbe. (The cow eats grass.)
Le bâtiment est vieux. (The building is old.)
La montagne est enneigée. (The mountain is snowy.)
Nous allons à la plage. (We are going to the beach.)
L'océan est calme aujourd'hui. (The ocean is calm today.)
La mer est belle ce matin. (The sea is beautiful this morning.)
Le jardin est plein de fleurs. (The garden is full of flowers.)

when_to_say: When referring to a trip or journey.
example: J'ai un voyage à Paris. (I have a trip to Paris.)
L'avion part à 9h. (The airplane leaves at 9 o'clock.)

when_to_say: When referring to a train station.
example: La gare est loin. (The train station is far.)
Je prends le bus pour aller au travail. (I take the bus to go to work.)
Le chaton est mignon. (The kitten is cute.)
Le chiot joue avec sa balle. (The puppy plays with its ball.)
La lune brille dans le ciel. (The moon is shining in the sky.)
Le soleil est très chaud aujourd'hui. (The sun is very hot today.)
Il y a des nuages dans le ciel. (There are clouds in the sky.)
La pluie tombe doucement. (The rain is falling softly.)
La neige couvre le sol. (The snow covers the ground.)
Le vent souffle fort. (The wind is blowing hard.)
C'était une journée merveilleuse. (It was a wonderful day.)

when_to_say: When describing something as old or ancient.
example: Ce bâtiment est ancien. (This building is old.)
J'ai un nouveau livre. (I have a new book.)
Le ciel est bleu. (The sky is blue.)
L'étoile brille la nuit. (The star shines at night.)
La forêt est dense. (The forest is dense.)
Nous nageons dans le lac. (We are swimming in the lake.)
La rivière est large. (The river is wide.)

when_to_say: When referring to a hill or a mount.
example: Le mont est très haut. (The hill is very high.)
La plante a besoin de soleil. (The plant needs sunlight.)

when_to_say: When referring to a nut tree.
example: L'arbre à noix produit des noisettes. (The nut tree produces hazelnuts.)
Le fruit est mûr. (The fruit is ripe.)
L'oiseau chante dans l'arbre. (The bird is singing in the tree.)
Le poisson nage dans l'eau. (The fish swims in the water.)
La souris mange du fromage. (The mouse eats cheese.)
Le serpent est long et sinueux. (The snake is long and winding.)
Le cheval galope dans le champ. (The horse gallops in the field.)
Le cochon se roule dans la boue. (The pig rolls in the mud.)
L'agneau suit sa mère. (The lamb follows its mother.)
L'éléphant a de grandes oreilles. (The elephant has large ears.)
La girafe mange des feuilles d'arbres. (The giraffe eats tree leaves.)
Le singe grimpe aux arbres. (The monkey climbs the trees.)
Le papillon vole autour des fleurs. (The butterfly flies around the flowers.)
La libellule vole près de l'eau. (The dragonfly flies near the water.)
La mouette vole au-dessus de la mer. (The seagull flies over the sea.)
Le canard nage dans l'étang. (The duck swims in the pond.)
Le poulet est dans le poulailler. (The chicken is in the chicken coop.)
L'autruche court très vite. (The ostrich runs very fast.)
La baleine nage dans l'océan. (The whale swims in the ocean.)
Le requin nage dans la mer. (The shark swims in the sea.)
Le dauphin saute hors de l'eau. (The dolphin jumps out of the water.)
La tortue se déplace lentement. (The turtle moves slowly.)
Le panda mange du bambou. (The panda eats bamboo.)
Le koala dort dans un arbre. (The koala sleeps in a tree.)
Le zèbre a des rayures noires et blanches. (The zebra has black and white stripes.)
Le kangourou saute dans la prairie. (The kangaroo jumps in the meadow.)
Le crocodile nage dans la rivière. (The crocodile swims in the river.)
Le chaton joue avec une balle. (The kitten is playing with a ball.)
Le chiot dort dans son panier. (The puppy is sleeping in its basket.)
L'agneau boit du lait. (The lamb is drinking milk.)

when_to_say: When referring to a young deer.
example: Le faon marche près de sa mère. (The fawn walks next to its mother.)
Le crocodile dort au bord de la rivière. (The crocodile is sleeping by the riverbank.)
Le mouton mange de l'herbe. (The sheep eats grass.)
Le chevreuil court dans la forêt. (The deer runs in the forest.)

when_to_say: When referring to a wild boar.
example: Le sanglier fouille dans le sol. (The wild boar digs in the ground.)
Le renard chasse dans la forêt. (The fox hunts in the forest.)
Le hibou hulule la nuit. (The owl hoots at night.)
Le loup hurle à la lune. (The wolf howls at the moon.)
Le pigeon vole dans le ciel. (The pigeon flies in the sky.)
La colombe vole dans le parc. (The dove flies in the park.)
Le flamant rose se tient sur une patte. (The flamingo stands on one leg.)
Le pélican pêche dans l'eau. (The pelican fishes in the water.)
Le perroquet répète des mots. (The parrot repeats words.)
Le canari chante dans sa cage. (The canary sings in its cage.)
La perruche mange des graines. (The budgie eats seeds.)
L'autruche court à toute vitesse. (The ostrich runs at full speed.)
Le papillon de nuit vole près de la lumière. (The moth flies near the light.)
L'araignée tisse une toile. (The spider spins a web.)
Le scorpion se cache sous la roche. (The scorpion hides under the rock.)
Les fourmis travaillent dur. (The ants work hard.)
La libellule vole au-dessus de l'eau. (The dragonfly flies above the water.)
L'abeille butine les fleurs. (The bee collects nectar from the flowers.)
Le ciel est bleu. (The sky is blue.)
Le nuage est blanc. (The cloud is white.)
Il pleut, il y a de la pluie. (It’s raining, there is rain.)
La neige tombe du ciel. (The snow is falling from the sky.)
Le vent souffle fort. (The wind is blowing strongly.)
L'arc-en-ciel est magnifique. (The rainbow is beautiful.)
L'étoile brille dans le ciel. (The star is shining in the sky.)
La lune est pleine ce soir. (The moon is full tonight.)
Le soleil brille. (The sun is shining.)
C'était une journée merveilleuse. (It was a wonderful day.)
Le paysage est magnifique. (The landscape is magnificent.)
C'est une histoire incroyable. (It’s an incredible story.)

when_to_say: When describing a person as nice or friendly.
example: Elle est très sympathique. (She is very friendly.)

when_to_say: When describing a person as kind.
example: Il est gentil avec les animaux. (He is kind to animals.)
Je suis très heureux aujourd'hui. (I am very happy today.)
Elle est triste parce qu'elle a perdu son chien. (She is sad because she lost her dog.)
Je suis fatigué après la course. (I am tired after the race.)
Je suis affamé, il est temps de manger. (I’m hungry, it’s time to eat.)
J'ai faim. (I am hungry.)
J'ai soif, je veux de l'eau. (I am thirsty, I want water.)
Je mange un sandwich pour le déjeuner. (I’m eating a sandwich for lunch.)
Nous avons un grand dîner ce soir. (We have a big dinner tonight.)
Je mange des croissants au petit-déjeuner. (I eat croissants for breakfast.)
J'adore le fromage. (I love cheese.)
Je mange du pain avec du fromage. (I eat bread with cheese.)
Je mange des fruits tous les jours. (I eat fruit every day.)
Les légumes sont bons pour la santé. (Vegetables are good for health.)
J'aime manger du poisson. (I like to eat fish.)
Je n'aime pas manger de viande. (I don't like to eat meat.)
La soupe est chaude. (The soup is hot.)
Je mange une salade avec du poulet. (I’m eating a salad with chicken.)

when_to_say: When referring to chicken as food.
example: J'adore le poulet rôti. (I love roasted chicken.)
Je prends une boisson froide. (I’m having a cold drink.)

Je bois du jus d'orange. (I’m drinking orange juice.)
Je prends un café le matin. (I have coffee in the morning.)
Elle aime boire du thé vert. (She likes to drink green tea.)
Je mange du chocolat noir. (I’m eating dark chocolate.)
J'ai fait un gâteau au chocolat. (I made a chocolate cake.)

when_to_say: When referring to a cookie or biscuit.
example: J'aime les biscuits au chocolat. (I like chocolate cookies.)

when_to_say: When referring to a chocolate-filled pastry.
example: J'adore le pain au chocolat. (I love chocolate croissants.)
Je mange un croissant au petit déjeuner. (I’m eating a croissant for breakfast.)
Je mange un sandwich au jambon. (I’m eating a ham sandwich.)
Je commande une pizza. (I’m ordering a pizza.)
J’aime les pâtes à la bolognaise. (I like pasta with Bolognese sauce.)
Je mange du saumon grillé. (I’m eating grilled salmon.)
Je mange un steak de bœuf. (I’m eating a beef steak.)
Je fais des côtes de porc. (I’m making pork ribs.)
Le mouton rôti est délicieux. (The roasted lamb is delicious.)

when_to_say: When referring to pepper (as a spice).
example: J’ajoute du poivre à la soupe. (I add pepper to the soup.)
J’ajoute du sel à la soupe. (I add salt to the soup.)
Je mets du sucre dans mon café. (I put sugar in my coffee.)
Je fais cuire les légumes dans de l'huile d'olive. (I cook the vegetables in olive oil.)
Le vinaigre est utilisé pour les salades. (Vinegar is used for salads.)
Je mange des légumes tous les jours. (I eat vegetables every day.)
J'adore les carottes crues. (I love raw carrots.)
J’ai acheté des tomates au marché. (I bought tomatoes at the market.)
Les poivrons sont délicieux dans les salades. (Bell peppers are delicious in salads.)
J’aime les haricots verts. (I like green beans.)
Le brocoli est riche en vitamines. (Broccoli is rich in vitamins.)
Le céleri est croquant. (Celery is crunchy.)
Je mange du poisson grillé. (I’m eating grilled fish.)
Les crevettes sont délicieuses. (The shrimp are delicious.)
Les moules sont fraîches. (The mussels are fresh.)
Nous avons mangé du homard au dîner. (We ate lobster for dinner.)
Les escargots sont un plat traditionnel français. (Snails are a traditional French dish.)
Le canard est délicieux avec de l'orange. (Duck is delicious with orange.)
L'agneau rôti est un plat savoureux. (Roast lamb is a flavorful dish.)
La baleine nage dans l'océan. (The whale swims in the ocean.)
Le dauphin saute dans l'eau. (The dolphin jumps in the water.)
Le requin nage dans la mer. (The shark swims in the sea.)
La tortue marche lentement. (The turtle walks slowly.)
Le serpent est dans l'herbe. (The snake is in the grass.)
L'oiseau chante dans l'arbre. (The bird sings in the tree.)
Le papillon vole dans le jardin. (The butterfly is flying in the garden.)
La fourmi porte une feuille. (The ant is carrying a leaf.)
L'abeille butine les fleurs. (The bee is collecting nectar from the flowers.)
La mouche vole autour de la nourriture. (The fly is flying around the food.)
L'araignée tisse sa toile. (The spider is weaving its web.)
Nous avons mangé des calmars grillés. (We ate grilled squid.)

when_to_say: When referring to chicken (as an animal or food).
example: Le poulet est délicieux. (The chicken is delicious.)
Le lapin mange des carottes. (The rabbit is eating carrots.)
Le cochon se roule dans la boue. (The pig is rolling in the mud.)
Le cheval court dans le champ. (The horse is running in the field.)
L'âne porte des sacs. (The donkey is carrying bags.)
La vache mange de l'herbe. (The cow is eating grass.)
La poule pond des œufs. (The hen lays eggs.)
Nous mangeons de la dinde à Noël. (We eat turkey at Christmas.)

when_to_say: When referring to a guinea fowl.
example: La pintade est servie au dîner. (The guinea fowl is served at dinner.)
Le pigeon vole dans le parc. (The pigeon is flying in the park.)
Le canard nage dans le lac. (The duck is swimming in the lake.)
Le papillon se pose sur la fleur. (The butterfly lands on the flower.)
Le singe mange une banane. (The monkey is eating a banana.)
La girafe mange des feuilles. (The giraffe is eating leaves.)
Le lion rugit dans la savane. (The lion roars in the savanna.)
Elle économise pour un voyage. (She is saving for a trip.)
Il veut investir dans l'immobilier. (He wants to invest in real estate.)

when_to_say: When talking about lending money or items.
example: Je peux te prêter de l'argent. (I can lend you some money.)

when_to_say: When talking about borrowing money or items.
example: Je vais emprunter un livre à la bibliothèque. (I am going to borrow a book from the library.)
Je vais à la banque pour retirer de l'argent. (I am going to the bank to withdraw money.)

when_to_say: When referring to an account (bank, email, etc.).
example: J'ai un compte bancaire en ligne. (I have an online bank account.)
Les intérêts de mon prêt sont élevés. (The interest on my loan is high.)
Elle a demandé un prêt à la banque. (She applied for a loan at the bank.)

when_to_say: When referring to salary or wages.
example: Son salaire est assez élevé. (His salary is quite high.)
Il a plusieurs sources de revenu. (He has several sources of income.)
Mes dépenses mensuelles sont élevées. (My monthly expenses are high.)
L'investissement dans l'immobilier peut être rentable. (Investment in real estate can be profitable.)
Je vais au marché pour acheter des légumes. (I am going to the market to buy vegetables.)

when_to_say: When referring to the stock market.
example: La bourse a chuté aujourd'hui. (The stock market fell today.)

when_to_say: When referring to shares or stocks in the market.
example: Il a acheté des actions de l'entreprise. (He bought shares in the company.)

when_to_say: When referring to a company or business.
example: Elle dirige une petite entreprise. (She runs a small business.)
L'employé travaille dans le bureau. (The employee works in the office.)
L'employeur offre de bons avantages. (The employer offers good benefits.)
J'ai signé un contrat de travail. (I signed a work contract.)
La réunion commence à 9h. (The meeting starts at 9 AM.)
Il fait du télétravail trois jours par semaine. (He works remotely three days a week.)

when_to_say: When referring to a promotion at work.
example: Elle a eu une promotion cette année. (She got a promotion this year.)

when_to_say: When referring to a layoff or dismissal.
example: Il a été victime d'un licenciement économique. (He was a victim of an economic layoff.)
Le recrutement de nouveaux employés est en cours. (The recruitment of new employees is ongoing.)

when_to_say: When referring to a job candidate.
example: Le candidat a une grande expérience. (The candidate has a lot of experience.)

when_to_say: When describing someone who is accountable for something.
example: Elle est responsable de l'équipe. (She is responsible for the team.)
J'ai une voiture rouge. (I have a red car.)

when_to_say: When referring to the act of working.
example: Je travaille à l'école. (I work at the school.)

when_to_say: When describing the level of difficulty in something.
example: Cette question a beaucoup de difficulté. (This question is very difficult.)

when_to_say: When talking about knowledge or information.
example: Je sais la réponse. (I know the answer.)

when_to_say: When referring to an educational institution.
example: L'école commence à huit heures. (School starts at eight o'clock.)
C'est une décision très importante. (It’s a very important decision.)

when_to_say: When talking about speaking or communicating.
example: Nous parlons français. (We speak French.)
Salut, comment ça va ? (Hi, how are you?)

when_to_say: When talking about where someone lives.
example: J'habite à Paris. (I live in Paris.)

when_to_say: When describing something crucial or that cannot be bypassed.
example: Ce livre est incontournable pour les étudiants en littérature. (This book is essential for literature students.)

when_to_say: Used when referring to something that goes against a constitution.
example: Cet acte a été fait anticonstitutionnellement. (This act was done unconstitutionally.)

when_to_say: When referring to changes or variations, particularly in data or conditions.
example: La fluctuation des prix est inquiétante. (The fluctuation of prices is worrying.)

when_to_say: When referring to deception or a trick used to achieve a goal.
example: Il a utilisé un subterfuge pour éviter la punition. (He used a subterfuge to avoid the punishment.)

when_to_say: When explaining or making something clear.
example: Le professeur a élucidé le problème complexe. (The teacher elucidated the complex issue.)

when_to_say: When referring to the action of delaying or postponing something.
example: Sa procrastination a retardé le projet. (His procrastination delayed the project.)

when_to_say: When referring to something that has multiple meanings or is unclear.
example: L'ambiguïté de la situation a créé des malentendus. (The ambiguity of the situation created misunderstandings.)

when_to_say: When referring to a division into two distinct and often opposite parts.
example: La dichotomie entre le bien et le mal est complexe. (The dichotomy between good and evil is complex.)

when_to_say: When referring to a unique characteristic or habit of an individual.
example: Sa idiosyncrasie le rendait difficile à comprendre. (His idiosyncrasy made him hard to understand.)

when_to_say: When referring to a concept that is theoretical rather than concrete.
example: L'abstraction dans la philosophie est un sujet complexe. (Abstraction in philosophy is a complex subject.)

when_to_say: When referring to the examination or interpretation of something.
example: L'analyse des données prend du temps. (The analysis of the data takes time.)

when_to_say: When talking about being familiar with people, places, or things.
example: Je connais bien cette ville. (I know this city well.)

when_to_say: When initiating or starting an activity or process.
example: Il faut démarrer le projet maintenant. (We need to start the project now.)
Je dois réfléchir à cette proposition. (I need to think about this proposal.)

when_to_say: When describing someone or something that is organized and systematic.
example: Il est très méthodique dans son travail. (He is very methodical in his work.)

when_to_say: When expressing uncertainty or lack of belief.
example: J'ai des doutes sur cette décision. (I have doubts about this decision.)

when_to_say: When referring to something that is not concrete or tangible.
example: L'art abstrait peut être difficile à comprendre. (Abstract art can be difficult to understand.)

when_to_say: When talking about the long-term sustainability or endurance of something.
example: La pérennité de l'entreprise dépend de ses choix. (The longevity of the company depends on its choices.)

when_to_say: When referring to something that is dependent on other factors.
example: Le succès de ce projet est contingent à de nombreux facteurs. (The success of this project is contingent on many factors.)

when_to_say: When referring to the act of acknowledging or appreciating something.
example: Elle a reçu de la reconnaissance pour son travail. (She received recognition for her work.)

when_to_say: When referring to something that is difficult to comprehend or obscure.
example: The professor's explanation of quantum physics was so abstruse that even the most advanced students struggled to follow.

meaning: accompanying, often in a secondary or subordinate way
when_to_say: When referring to something that naturally accompanies or is associated with something else.
example: The disease is often accompanied by a concomitant loss of appetite.

when_to_say: When describing someone or something that is treacherous or disloyal.
example: He was accused of perfidious behavior after betraying his closest allies for personal gain.

when_to_say: When referring to something that cannot be influenced or stopped.
example: The inexorable march of time waits for no one, no matter how hard we try to stop it.

meaning: lasting for a very short time
when_to_say: When referring to something that is brief, fleeting, or temporary.
example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral, disappearing as quickly as it arrived.

when_to_say: When describing someone who is wise or shows good judgment.
example: Her sagacious advice helped the company navigate through difficult times.

when_to_say: When referring to something that is widespread or everywhere.
example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous, with nearly everyone owning one.

meaning: a natural or habitual inclination or tendency
when_to_say: When referring to a tendency or natural preference for something.
example: She has a proclivity for helping others, always volunteering her time for charity.

when_to_say: When describing someone or something that is full of energy, vivacity, or cheerfulness.
example: Her effervescent personality made her the life of every party.

meaning: weak or faint from illness or fatigue; sluggish
when_to_say: When describing someone or something lacking in energy, vitality, or movement.
example: The hot weather left him feeling languid and unable to do anything.

meaning: to deliberately make something unclear or difficult to understand
when_to_say: When referring to the act of confusing or obscuring something intentionally.
example: The politician's answers only served to obfuscate the real issue.

meaning: a deep-seated feeling of dislike or aversion
when_to_say: When describing a strong feeling of opposition or hostility towards something.
example: She felt an intense antipathy toward the idea of moving to a new city.

meaning: unwilling to change one's views or to agree about something
when_to_say: When describing someone who is inflexible or refuses to compromise.
example: His intransigent attitude made it impossible to reach a consensus.

meaning: characterized by bitter and abusive language
when_to_say: When describing language or behavior that is harshly critical or abusive.
example: The vituperative remarks of the critic discouraged many artists.

meaning: having little or no money; poor
when_to_say: When describing someone who is financially poor or destitute.
example: The impecunious artist struggled to make ends meet, despite his talent.

when_to_say: When describing someone who is prone to deception or falsehood.
example: The mendacious politician misled the public with exaggerated claims.

when_to_say: When describing someone or something that is marked by strong, loud noise.
example: The vociferous protests echoed through the streets.

when_to_say: When referring to great beauty, especially of a person.
example: The actress's pulchritude captivated audiences around the world.

when_to_say: When describing someone who betrays trust or is unfaithful.
example: He was accused of perfidious behavior after betraying his closest allies.

meaning: behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others
when_to_say: When describing someone who has an attitude of arrogance or condescension.
example: Her supercilious smile irritated everyone in the room.

meaning: sparing or moderate in eating and drinking
when_to_say: When referring to someone who is moderate in consumption or avoids indulgence.
example: His abstemious lifestyle contributed to his long life.

when_to_say: When describing someone who is disobedient or difficult to manage.
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the school rules.

meaning: generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person
when_to_say: When describing someone who is noble and generous in spirit, especially in forgiving others.
example: His magnanimous gesture toward his former competitor earned him widespread respect.

meaning: mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper
when_to_say: When referring to the ability to remain calm and composed in difficult situations.
example: Despite the chaos around her, she maintained her equanimity.

meaning: expressing opinions in a pompously moralizing way
when_to_say: When describing someone who tends to make moralistic or preachy statements, often in a self-important manner.
example: His sententious remarks about hard work felt out of place in the casual conversation.

meaning: the occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
when_to_say: When describing a fortunate accident or unexpected discovery.
example: It was pure serendipity that they met on the same flight to Paris.

meaning: to repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement)
when_to_say: When referring to the official ending or cancellation of something.
example: The government decided to abrogate the outdated law.

when_to_say: When referring to something that is mysterious, difficult to interpret, or incomprehensible.
example: The inscrutable expression on her face made it difficult to know what she was thinking.

meaning: essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison
when_to_say: When referring to things that are fundamentally different or incomparable.
example: The two cultures were so disparate that they had difficulty understanding each other.

meaning: excessive confidence or boldness, often to the point of rashness
when_to_say: When describing excessive daring or recklessness.
example: She had the temerity to challenge the CEO's decision in front of the entire board.

meaning: vigorous or incisive in expression or style
when_to_say: When describing someone or something that is sharply focused or effective in speech or writing.
example: His trenchant comments about the issue left no room for debate.

when_to_say: When referring to the most important or prominent feature of something.
example: The salient points of the report were highlighted during the presentation.

meaning: peculiar or individual in nature or character
when_to_say: When referring to something that is characteristic of an individual or group, often in a unique or unusual way.
example: His idiosyncratic sense of humor made him stand out in the crowd.

meaning: using few words; brief and concise
when_to_say: When describing someone who speaks sparingly or succinctly.
example: His laconic responses often left people wondering what he truly thought.

meaning: having an extremely offensive smell; harmful or noxious
when_to_say: When describing something that is foul-smelling or harmful to health.
example: The noisome odor from the garbage heap made it impossible to walk nearby.

when_to_say: When describing someone who is disobedient or difficult to manage.
example: The recalcitrant employee refused to follow company policies.

meaning: using few words; brief and concise
when_to_say: When referring to someone who speaks sparingly or succinctly.
example: His laconic style of communication made him an enigmatic figure.

meaning: directly opposed or contrasted; mutually incompatible
when_to_say: When describing something that is in direct opposition or contradiction.
example: Their views on environmental policy were antithetical to each other.

when_to_say: When referring to something that is hard to grasp or comprehend.
example: The professor's lecture on quantum mechanics was so abstruse that even graduate students struggled to follow.

when_to_say: When describing a sound that is deep, sorrowful, or mournful.
example: The plangent tones of the church bell echoed through the empty streets.

meaning: generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person
when_to_say: When describing someone who is noble and generous in spirit, especially in forgiving others.
example: The magnanimous gesture of granting the rival's request was unexpected.

meaning: to repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement)
when_to_say: When referring to the formal cancellation of a law or agreement.
example: The government decided to abrogate the outdated policy.

meaning: to deliberately make something unclear or difficult to understand
when_to_say: When referring to the act of making something confusing or unclear.
example: The company's financial report was designed to obfuscate the true state of affairs.

meaning: worthy of respect due to age, dignity, or character
when_to_say: When referring to someone or something deserving of reverence because of their age or esteemed qualities.
example: The venerable professor was highly regarded by students and faculty alike.
